node.text:
🍣 SUSHI WITH KIDS // Before you scroll past this post, because you think making sushi with your kids is too hard, STOP! 🛑 Let me tell you, it is totally doable and the results are deeelicious! 🤩 We used @gimmegrams sushi nori, which is restaurant-quality and organic! 🤤 Just watch the full video 📹 to see my 3 year old in action, and read on below👇 for the step-by-step instructions and some tips to make things as easy as possible! 🙌
-
💚 Sponsored 💚 
-
HERE’S WHAT YOU NEED
• 2 cups sushi rice cooked, we made ours in an instant pot!
• Rice Vinegar
• Sugar
• Salt
• gimMe Sushi Nori
• Sesame Seed
• Avocado
• Cucumber
• Imitation Crab
-
HOW TO
(1) Season the sushi rice to taste, we added about 1/4 cup vinegar, 1/2 tsp sugar, and 1 tsp salt;
(2) On top of a rolling mat, place one sheet of gimMe Sushi Nori (rough side up!);
(3) Spread the sushi rice on top in an even layer. (Wet your hands as needed!)
(4) Sprinkle sesame seeds on top of the rice;
(5) Flip the rice-covered nori over;
(6) On top of the nori, arrange slices of avocado, slices of cucumber, and imitation crab, leaving 1 inch of rice from the bottom.
(7) Roll the mat over, keeping the filling in place with your fingers, so that you make a tight log!
(8) Remove the rolling mat, and (grown ups!) use a sharp, wet knife to slice into pieces.
-
TIPS
• PREP THE MATERIALS: Having the items prepped will make the process run so much smoother.
-
• STICKY SOLUTION: The very nature of sushi rice is that it is sticky! Have plenty of dish towels and a bowl of water nearby to reset clean hands!
-
• SLICING THE SUSHI: My 3yo tried slicing the sushi with his kid-friendly knife, but it was not sharp enough to do the job! So have a grown-up do this part!
-

node.text:
If you have a picky eater (or as I like to say, a selective eater), then you know introducing new or different foods can be a challenge! 😅 But, oh. my. gosh! 😍 Here is an activity, that brought the fun back to our kitchen table! 🤩 We approached this experiment-style, noting exposure to a new food through sight, feel, and ultimately taste! 👅 I gave my selective eater 4 new foods to explore —  @gimmegrams seaweed, kiwi, pan de yuca, and sautéed carrots — and his exploration of each was absolutely amazing! 🙌 I’d love to know whether you’ll try this too! Or if you know a friend who this activity might benefit, be sure to share it with them! 👌 Any questions at all? Drop👇 them in the comment section below, or DM me!
-
#gimmepartner #gimmeseaweed

node.text:
This diy counting board is the perfect tactile resource for early math learning! 🤩 The removable cards and moveable wooden beads are perfect for some hands on fun. 🙌 While this craft certainly takes a little more effort to create than most of our activities, the good news is, it is a resource we come back to time and time again! 👌 Plus, it is super adaptable for children at different math levels as you can add as many beads as you like! 👍 Read on below👇for the how-to and if you have any questions at all, send me a direct message!
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
• 2 pieces of identical Cardboard, and additional cardboard for number cards
• Twine or thick string
• Beads
• Glue
• Hole punch
-
HOW TO
(1) Using a sharp knife, cut out 2 rectangular shapes on one of the cardboard pieces. This is where the number cards will go.
(2) Then cut out a thin, long rectangle below. This is where the tactile counting beads will go.
(3) Punch a hole on each end of the rectangle;
(4) Tie a piece of twine through one hole securely;
(5) Thread the beads onto the twine and secure the beads by tying the other end to the hole;
(6) Glue the 2 cardboard pieces together, with the beads and cut out pieces on the top;
(7) Take scrap cardboard, and cut out rectangle shapes for the number cards;
(8) On each rectangle, write each number. If counting to 20, you’ll need two 1s. If counting to 30, you’ll need an additional two 2s, and so forth. Now the board is ready for some serious counting fun!
-

node.text:
A budget friendly alphabet game using wooden spoons and a cardboard box. ♻️ It’s a fun hands on diy alternative to an alphabet puzzle. Adapt this based on your kiddo’s skill level - using lowercase letters, numbers, or even colors too! 👌 Plus, aiming the thin bases of the spoon through those small slots is great for hand eye coordination and fine motor skills in general! 🙌 Save this post so you remember to do it later and share it with a friend who might want to make it too! 💕
-

Let’s work out those fine motor skills using an old cardboard box, 📦 bottle caps to twist, and pom poms to push! ♻️ Head to my stories on how you can make this diy toy, or if you miss it, just send me a direct message and I’ll send it your way! 👌 This is such a great, budget-friendly way to learn colors while strengthening those critical small muscles in hands and fingers! 🙌
-
Don’t forget to save this idea so you do it later and share it with a friend who might want to make it too!
-
Caution - Small parts! Adult supervision required. You can use cereal instead of pom poms if there is any concerns!
-

node.text:
Big news! 🎉 Get 10% off your Guardian Bikes order with code 7daysofplay. 🤩 We can barely contain our excitement because not only is this something the company has never done before, but they’ve chosen to give it exclusively to you, my followers! 🙌 Head to my link in bio to see their selection and use code 7daysofplay for 10% off - they sell out fast! Plus, visit my stories to see the bikes in action! Why did I choose @guardianbikes for my kids above all the other options out there? Read on below👇for all the details! Oh, and remember — it’s never too early to start shopping for the holidays! 🎁 
-
Why We Love Guardian Bikes
-
Safety. They have a patented brake system called SureStop, it is a single brake system that controls braking on both wheels - this avoids confusion and keeps things simple for kids. It also prevents head-over-handlebar accidents, distributing the right amount of braking power to both wheels which also prevents front wheel skidding. 
-
Great Design. Not only are the geometric patterns and colors super cool, but they are lightweight, have a low cross bar to help kids get on easily, double walled rims to stand up to rough kids play, and an adjustable seat that grows with your child.
-
They Understand Sizing. They are all about sizing based on inseam and rider experience. They have a handy guide on their website that walks you through the process to get the sizing right!
-

Sticky paper activity ideas! 🤗 Swipe 👉 to see more fun ways to play with this very handy paper! What’s sticky paper? It’s an adhesive paper typically used for covering surfaces and lining things like drawers and shelves, but it’s also a great tool for play activities! 👌 We love to slap it up on a the wall for a vertical surface that encourages shoulder strength, gross motors skills, and lasting engagement (to name a few!). 🙌 Save this post so you don’t forget to do these ideas later! 💕 And if you have any questions about any of these ideas, send me a direct message because I’ll track down the original post and send it to you! ✨

node.text:
Who is able to stay positive in a doom and gloom world? 😬 I know it can be hard, but I constantly remind myself of the power of positivity. ✨ No doubt, our planet is suffering - from global warming, to air pollution, and habitat loss (to name a few). And listen, I’m all about being honest with my children and giving them the stone cold facts - like, how plant and animal species are threatened by human activity taking place on +83% of the earth’s land surface. 🌎 BUT if we only focus on the doom and gloom, how can we encourage solution seeking? Allowing kids to experience nature, 🌱 to touch the earth, plant seeds, and enjoy Mother Nature’s gifts is the first step in raising kids who not only care about this planet, but fight for it. 💪 Swimming in water and observing marine habitats 🏝is the first step in understanding the importance of eliminating plastic consumption so that kids fully understand what it means that by 2050 there will be more plastic in our oceans than fish. 🐠 And the list goes on and on. So here’s to constructive honesty — letting our kids know the realities while encouraging positive change. 📣
-
I absolutely love this quote by Nicolette from @awilderchild — share it with someone who may need to hear it today!
-

node.text:
Making budget-friendly and vibrant activities with our Canon PIXMA MegaTank Printer! 🌈 Link in bio to get the free printable plus more info about our printer! 🙌 Read on below👇 for the simple steps and tips for creating this fun color matching activity that is also great for strengthening fine motor skills! 💪 And don’t forget to save this post so you remember to do it later!! 💕
-
TIPS
-
Budget Friendly Printer. We love the @Canon PIXMA MegaTank Printers because they are budget-friendly and produce super vibrant colors! Its refillable MegaTank ink system prints up to 6,000 black / 7,700 color pages from one set of ink bottles— that’s 30 times what you can print with a conventional ink cartridge set!
-
Choice of Color. We love liquid watercolor because you can dilute it significantly and still have incredibly vibrant colors - lots more bang for your buck than food coloring! You could also simply use a paintbrush and watercolors too!
-
Laminate. I would highly recommend using a laminator because this is an activity your little one is going to want to do over and over again! Just swap out the colored cotton swabs for fresh ones and toddlers and preschoolers can keep on learning colors over and over again!
-
HOW TO
-
(1) Print out our free printable worksheet and laminate for multiple uses. Link in bio!
(2) Use double-sided tape to stick cotton rounds inside the circles on the worksheet.
(3) Dilute liquid watercolor with water in individual containers and provide large droppers. Alternatively, provide a liquid watercolor set and paint brush.
(4) Task your kiddo with using a dropper to soak up the liquid watercolor and drop it onto the correct cotton pads.
-

node.text:
Anyone know a kiddo struggling with fine motor skills? When my oldest was 3, he was struggling big time. 😫 I knew that working on his scissor skills would help him get on the right track, but just handing him scissors and a paper wasn't going to do the trick! 🙅‍♀️ He needed to be engaged, and so I found creative ways for him to explore cutting skills, like this silly pet salon activity! 🐩 Fast forward two years, and my oldest no longer struggles! 😍 Thanks to fun activities like this, he strengthened the muscles he needed to start writing like a champ! 💪
- Head to my link in bio for all the details on how I set this up and to see our selection of free scissor skills printable worksheets!
-
Save this post so you don’t forget to do it later!
-

node.text:
Who else is constantly second guessing whether they took (or gave) the medicine or not? 🙋‍♀️ This hack for keeping track of dosages has been a life saver for me, especially when tasked with giving a 10 day antibiotics prescription for my little one! 😅 We slapped a plain label on the bottle to track everything, but you can write directly on the bottle itself! 🙌
-
Share this with a friend who needs to know this!

node.text:
This sand play dough recipe is so easy to make a fun way for kids to deeply engage in ocean-themed sensory play! 🏖 Read on below 👇 for our simple no-cook recipe as well as some important tips for making the perfect batch! 🙌 Don’t forget to save this post so you remember to do it later! 💕
-
Tips for Making the Perfect Batch
-
Wear gloves while mixing the water! The mixture will be very hot so protect yourself with gloves and keep the kiddos away!
-
Why is my batch too sticky? Too much water was added! If too sticky add a little more flour.
-
Why is my batch too dry? Not enough water was added! If too dry add a little more water.
-
Do I need to add oil? The coconut oil gives the dough a super silky texture. You could also use glycerine. Alternatively, other vegetable oil will work too, but I’ve found that coconut oil makes it super silky!
-
What is cream of tartar, and do I need it? The cream of tartar is a preservative and it makes the play dough have a longer shelf life. You can omit it, but the dough will not last as long!
-
WHAT YOU’LL NEED
* 1 cup play sand
* 1/2 cup of all-purpose flour
* 1/3 cup of fine salt
* 1 tablespoon of cream of tartar
* 2 tablespoons of coconut oil (optional)
* 3/4 cup of boiling water
* Storage Jars (optional)
-
HOW TO
Step 1
Mix together the sand, flour, salt, and cream of tartar in a bowl.
Step 2
Add the coconut oil for a soft and silky texture. You can also use food-grade glycerine.
Step 3
Boil the water. In my microwave, it takes about 2 minutes to reach best temperature.
Step 4
Mix the water to the flour mixture, transfering to a flat surface to knead until smooth and not sticky. Don't miss my note above about wearing gloves to protect your hands from the heat!
-

node.text:
Who else is constantly reminding themselves that their kiddo can totally do something on their own? 🙋‍♀️ Whether it’s related to self-care (think: putting shoes on 👟 and getting dressed), helping with chores (like putting away the dishes or making the bed 🛏 ), or helping with mealtime (for example, food prep and setting the table 🍴). The list goes on and on. And sure, I totally get it, with the hustle and bustle of our busy days, ⏰ in that very moment, we may want to quickly complete something that will take longer for a child to do. But, we must remind ourselves to wait! Just imagine how much easier life with kids would be, if they are given the time to learn these very important life skills. 🙌 Not to mention, the VERY important benefits you are giving them for their future — guiding them on the perfect path of being independent, responsible, doers. 💪
-
